text: I'll revert back to what I was talking to you about in terms of ALM in general. When you start looking at an ALM plan, your return bogey is the discount rate that is being earned by the liability because that's what its growth rate is. And your volatility is the tracking error between your asset return and your liability return. If that's the case, then myself and a colleague at UPS have actually written a paper on this. It's in a white paper now. Now, it hasn't been published yet, but we've had a lot of interest where we said, well, if that is what the real bogeys are for the ALM study, then isn't that a sharp ratio, but from an ALM perspective? So if you look at the numerator, you're looking at, okay, well, you have your return on your assets minus your return on your discount rate all over the tracking error between your assets and liability. That is your efficiency. That's how good you're doing running an ALM portfolio. And if that's the case, then just like the sharp. You can use it to decide whether you want to bring another asset class or another beta exposure into the mix. Just like the sharp ratio, what's the correlation between its return and the return of the combined portfolio? And does it fit? Is it accretive to the ALM sharp ratio? And if it is, then it's a viable strategy to be included.
